message_1: In intuitionistic logic, let P be a true statement and Q be a false statement. Determine the truth value of the statement: (P OR Q) AND (NOT P OR Q).
message_2:
In intuitionistic logic, we have the following truth values for P and Q:

P is true
Q is false

Now, let's analyze the given statement: (P OR Q) AND (NOT P OR Q)

1. (P OR Q): Since P is true, the whole statement (P OR Q) is true.

2. (NOT P OR Q): Since P is true, NOT P is false. Now we have (false OR Q), and since Q is false, the whole statement (NOT P OR Q) is false.

Now we have the final statement: (true) AND (false)

In intuitionistic logic, a statement is true if and only if it can be proven. In this case, (true) AND (false) cannot be proven, so the statement is false.
